awd_titl_txt: Catalytic Cycloaddition Reactions and Their Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Chemical Catalysis (CAT) and Chemical Synthesis (SYN) Programs in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Michael Doyle of the University of Texas, San Antonio is  working to develop new ways to construct molecules using vinyl diazo compounds, organic building blocks that have a carbon-carbon double bond next to an electron-poor carbon, formally known as a carbenoid center. Catalysts are being studied to tune and control the reactivity of vinyl diazo compounds with compatible reagents to access value-added products. These investigations are working toward establishing new ways to construct challenging bonds and heteroaromatic structures that are common components of valued added target molecules, particularly heterocyclic structures of value to biological and medicinal chemistry. Synergistically, these activities will provide opportunities for students of different levels to broaden their knowledge and experience in catalytic and synthetic chemistry. Undergraduate students are being integrated into the research program with strong mentoring that prepares them for careers in STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) disciplines, and opportunities are being provided to postdoctoral research associates to prepare them for positions in the chemical sciences in both the private sector and in academia.

New modular methods for the synthesis of heterocycles and functionalized carbocycles are in high demand due to the prevalence of these structures in pharmaceutical, agrochemical, and new material targets. Professor Michael Doyle and his research team are identifying catalysts that extrude molecular nitrogen from vinyl diazo-compounds to form highly energetic metallocarbene intermediates that condense with a variety of dipolar cycloaddition partners to form novel adduce with a high degree of regio- and stereo control. The stereodefined products of [3+1]-cycloaddition reactions of silyl-protected enoldiazo compounds will be studied for subsequent strain-induced ring-opening reactivity and used to explore cycloaddition reactions of donor-acceptor cycloalkenes. Acid-catalyzed conditions with triflimide are being developed to engage vinyl diazo [3+1] cycloaddition products in subsequent cycloaddition reactions that lead to intermediate structures capable of ring expansion to medium-sized products. Highly enantioselective catalytic cyclopropanation reactions of enoldiazo compounds are being tested to prepare donor-acceptor cyclopropanes that are capable of engaging in cycloaddition reactions with retention of enantioenrichement. These activities will take place at the University of Texas, San Antonio, and augment the inclusive training and research opportunities at this minority-serving institution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Access to complex organic compounds having high stereocontrol has been an overarching goal of this research, and we have explored multiple approaches to their synthesis. With support from the National Science Foundation beginning in the 1980s we have focused on the reactions of diazo compounds extending from their development, scope of synthesis, and generation af appropriate catalysts, to understanding their reaction mechanisms. Over the five three years we have concentrated on the chemical transformations of vinyldiazo compounds, especially those having a silyl ether substituent at the beta position of the vinyldiazoacetate, known as enoldiazoacetates. These diazo compounds have been demonstrated in our laboratory to undergo {3+3]-cycloaddition reactions with 1,3-dipoles, [3+2]-cycloaddition reactionns with selected alkenes and other unsaturated substrates, and, surprisingly, [3+1]-cycloadition with sulfur ylides and sulfur imides to produce four-menbered ring compounds in high yields and exceptional stereocontrol. In the course of establishing these transformations we also found that enoldiazoacetates underwent thermal, catalytic, and photochemical loss of dinitrogen that form donor-acceptor cyclopropenes that are stable photochemically and thermally, but revert to metallovinylcarbenes with selected catalysts. This discovery has led uo to examine the trapping of unstable cyclopropenes that are generated photochemically from vinyldiazo comounds by reactions with dipolar species. Another viable approach to previously undiscovered reactions entail the use of a strong protic acid, triflimide, to catalyze reactions of vinyldiazoacetates with electrophiles leading to the preparation of some very complex molecules in good yields with high selectivities.

These investigations have supported the education and training of numerous individuals who have further advanced their training by entrance to graduate school or further postdoctoral experience or entered either academic or industrial employment. Their contributions to this research are recognized by their coauthorship of publications from my group.

Another facet of the research supported by the National Science Foundation is the actual "spinoff" of ongoing research with new areas for development. One such "spinoff" from the vinyldiazoacetate chemistry is their reaction with alkyl nitrites that form 4-carboxylato-1,2,3-triazine 1-oxides in high yields. These compounds have been found to have amazing suitability for derivitisation and structural transformations that we are now exploring. In addition, some of these compounds exhibit significant biological effects, the most prominant thus far being actyivity against certain tropical diseases.


Last Modified: 01/27/2025
Modified by: Michael P Doyle
